caption.p: The information use sequence: definitions and examples.

tr.td: 1. Gaining knowledge of the location of a food patch. 2. Gaining knowledge of the location or form of a novel task.
An individual uses the information that it has acquired in a relevant (but not necessarily successful) way

1. Entering a food patch. Because information can become outdated, ‘application’ can occur even after the patch has been fully depleted, leading to no reward. 2. Using stimulus or local enhancement to manipulate a novel task, but not necessarily successfully.
An individual successfully uses information that it has acquired and applied to gain a benefit
1. Gaining food from a patch. 2. Solving a novel task.
